G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Now comes the Plaintiff, Lisa McKenzie (“Plaintiff”), pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and respectfully requests that this Honorable Court modify the existing custody and parenting time order entered on May 15, 2020, to reflect a material change in circumstances affecting the welfare of the minor children, Emma Johnson (age 8) and Noah Johnson (age 6).

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Now comes the Plaintiff, Lisa McKenzie (“Plaintiff”), pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and respectfully requests that this Honorable Court modify the existing custody and parenting time order entered on May 15, 2020, to reflect a material change in circumstances affecting the welfare of the minor children, Emma Johnson (age 8) and Noah Johnson (age 6).

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: This rearrangement of circumstances directly impacts the children’s best interests, which, under G.L. c. 208, § 31, are paramount in any custody determination.

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010) (court may modify custody when changed circumstances affect child’s welfare).
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: This concurring opinion in Smith v. McDonald is about statutory interpretation under the paternity statute and the limits of a judge’s authority to order a relocating, sole-legal parent to return to Massachusetts. It does not discuss the general standard for modification of custody based on changed circumstances affecting the child’s welfare. The opinion focuses instead on the mother’s right to relocate prior to adjudication of paternity and the inapplicability of removal jurisprudence such as Yannas, so it does not support the cited proposition about when a court may modify custody upon changed circumstances.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: The court concludes, and I concur, that the judge had no authority to issue an order during the pendency of litigation for the child (and hence the mother) to move back to Massachusetts. See ante at 550. As the court acknowledges, a person having sole parental rights is “free to move with the child wherever she wishe[s].” Id. at 549-550. As a matter of law, it should make no difference to a parent’s freedom to relocate that another party subsequently files to establish parental rights.

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006) (best interests remain controlling standard).
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the removal standard under G.L. c. 208, § 30 in a joint legal and physical custody context and explicitly holds that “cause shown” means a showing that removal is in the children’s best interests. The court repeatedly characterizes the governing inquiry as whether removal is in the children’s best interests and reviews the trial judge’s decision under that standard, thereby confirming that the best-interests test remains the controlling standard in this setting.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that… [a child] shall not… be removed out of this Commonwealth… without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders. ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’… We conclude that in such a situation ‘cause shown’ pursuant to G. L. c. 208, § 30, means a showing that removal is in the ‘best interests’ of the children taking into account all the circumstances….”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012) (stability and continuity are central to the best interests inquiry).
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion clearly applies a best-interests-of-the-child analysis and discusses stability, flexible work schedules, sibling relationships, and a parent’s attempts to undermine the other parent. However, it does not explicitly state that “stability and continuity are central” to the best-interests inquiry, and when listing relevant factors it cites other cases (e.g., Adoption of Kali, Haas) as the authority for stability considerations. Thus, while stability is discussed as a factor, Hunter v. Rose is not the originating or primary authority for the specific proposition as phrased.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’ … Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent. See Adoption of Kali, supra at 843, 847 (stability and flexible work schedule); … Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555, 557 (1980) (denial of custody where home was not ‘settled’ and child would be cared for by multiple providers rather than parent).”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001) (material change found where custodial schedule conflicted with parent’s work commitments).
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly rejects the notion that the mother’s changed work schedule or the court-imposed temporary schedule constituted a material and substantial change justifying modification of custody. The court holds that relocation and the temporary change in the custodial schedule (including any interaction with the parents’ work situations) could not serve as the required material change. Thus, the case stands for the opposite of the claimed proposition, rather than finding a material change based on schedule/work conflicts.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “We note, first, that a parent who works outside the home, even one with a ‘hectic’ schedule, may still be the appropriate primary caretaker and that, standing alone, such employment would not warrant a custody modification… Thus, to the extent that changes in the mother’s work schedule did occur, they were not changes warranting a modification in the custody arrangement.… That order… cannot form the basis upon which a final judgment modifying custody is granted.”

Ireland v. Ireland, 428 Mass. 1009 (1998.proposition: Ireland v. Ireland, 428 Mass. 1009 (1998) (employment changes warrant review of prior custody arrangements).
Ireland v. Ireland, 428 Mass. 1009 (1998.support_reasoning: The provided text is not Ireland v. Ireland, 428 Mass. 1009 (1998), but a criminal speedy‑trial decision (Commonwealth v. Amidon and related cases). It deals with Rule 36 speedy‑trial calculations, acquiescence in delay, and exclusion of time, and does not involve custody, family law, or employment changes. Therefore, it cannot support the proposition that employment changes warrant review of prior custody arrangements.
Ireland v. Ireland, 428 Mass. 1009 (1998.relevant_excerpt: “In sum, the Commonwealth has not justified thirty-three days of delay. Consequently, it violated the defendant’s right to a speedy trial under rule 36. We affirm the trial judge’s order dismissing indictments 940005, 940006, 940007, and 940008.”

Constantino v. Liu, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 81.raw_text: Constantino v. Liu, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 810 (2017)
Constantino v. Liu, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 81.proposition: Constantino v. Liu, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 810 (2017) (parent’s availability and supervision capabilities are central to custodial determinations).
Constantino v. Liu, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 81.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is not Constantino v. Liu at all; it is a criminal case involving a motion to withdraw a guilty plea in light of Annie Dookhan’s drug lab misconduct. It does not involve custody, parenting, or any discussion of a parent’s availability or supervision capabilities. Therefore, this opinion cannot support the proposition about factors central to custodial determinations.
Constantino v. Liu, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 81.relevant_excerpt: A motion to withdraw a guilty plea is treated as a motion for a new trial under Mass.R.Crim.P. 30(b)... The disposition of such a motion is ‘committed to the sound discretion of the judge.’ Scott, supra at 344. “[T]he judge’s findings of fact are to be accepted if supported by the evidence.” Ibid. “We review an order [on] a new trial motion to determine if the judge committed a significant error of law or other abuse of discretion.” Ibid.

Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).proposition: Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000) (the child’s stability and consistency of care take priority).
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).support_reasoning: The opinion is primarily about property division, alimony, and the procedural mechanism for modifying custody, not about a general principle that a child’s stability and consistency of care take priority. In the brief custody discussion, the court focuses on the children’s best interests, the parents’ insight into special needs, and the improper use of a motion instead of a complaint for modification; it does not articulate or prioritize a distinct doctrinal rule that stability and consistency of care override other factors. Any inference about stability is incidental and not stated as a controlling legal principle.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “If the judge felt that joint legal custody put the children at risk, or was not in their best interests, because of the wife’s worrisome parenting behavior, then the judge should have ordered sole legal custody to the father. She did not have discretion to fashion, even with the agreement of both parents, an alternative plan. Accordingly, we amend the order on custody to require the filing of a complaint for modification by the party who seeks to revise the order.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981) (court must revisit custody when circumstances change materially).
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion in Rolde v. Rolde is an appeal from an original divorce judgment addressing initial custody, property division, and visitation. It does not discuss modification of an existing custody order or set out a rule that a court must revisit custody when there is a material change in circumstances. The court focuses on the best-interests standard and deference to the trial judge’s discretion, not on standards or duties for later modification proceedings.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the children in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future, and it is a subject peculiarly within the discretion of the judge.”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981) (parent’s change in living or work situation necessitates review of parenting plan).
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss a parent’s change in living or work situation or say that such a change necessitates review of a parenting plan. Instead, it focuses on the requirement that custody determinations be based on the child’s best interests and criticizes a custody award grounded solely on the father’s alleged criminal conduct. The remand is for proper best-interests findings, not triggered by any change in a parent’s circumstances.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. … On rehearing, the findings should examine the relative advantages of the respective parental environments. Findings also would be appropriate concerning (1) the length of time the child has been in her present environment and under the primary care of her father at his home and (2) whether and in what respects that environment has been helpful or detrimental to the child’s well being.”

Penny v. Penny, 430 Mass. 24 (1999).proposition: Penny v. Penny, 430 Mass. 24 (1999) (the focus remains on promoting the welfare of the children amidst new facts).
